s.text: In True Crime , director Clint Eastwood demonstrates at once how far the medium has come in terms of race and how far it has backslid artistically--to about 1910.
He's someone you could actually imagine taking aside and asking, "Er, Robert, tell me ...
But this is not a man who strikes me--either in interviews or on the big screen--as being at home with words.
But this is not a man who strikes me--either in interviews or on the big screen--as being at home with words.

It's a bizarre concoction, but it's riveting--and I use that term advisedly, in the sense of a hack-'em-up serial killer riveting somebody's head to the side of a door.

On the plus side, it's ravishingly well directed by Antonia Bird ( Priest , 1995), who reportedly came on board two weeks after shooting had commenced and as such had little say about the thrust of the script.
I'd like to recommend it, but it's too silly.
Not even Robert Altman, who parodied this sort of climax in The Player , was cynical enough to let his sellout filmmaker play the intravenous card.

) while hollering out their names--at once thrilling the child and endangering her life.

The script, credited to Larry Gross, Paul Brickman, and Stephen Schiff (from a potboiler by Andrew Klavan), is often laughably schematic, but much of what's outside its ramrod narrative is masterfully orchestrated: the physical exam on Beachum that begins the film (he's in perfect health to be killed), the meetings between the warden and his guards on execution procedure, the testing of the different colored phones--one connected to the governor's office--outside the lethal injection chamber.
That's not an appetizing image, but I'm preparing you for Ravenous , the cannibal saga I predict will elicit the most derisive reviews of any film this year.

As a white journalist (played by Eastwood) hastens to save an innocent black man (Isaiah Washington) from execution for the murder of a pregnant white convenience-store cashier, Eastwood cuts from the reporter's car careening around hairpin curves to poison-bearing tubes being inserted into the black man's veins: screeching car, needle in vein, screeching car, poison descending the tube, screeching car, clock going tick-tick-tick, glazed expression on the dying man's face, screeech ...
In any case, it has become painful to listen to Eastwood talk.
In any case, it has become painful to listen to Eastwood talk.
He's someone you could actually imagine taking aside and asking, "Er, Robert, tell me ...
